section.title: Prerequisites for Integrating &EMR; with &DDB;
section.para: To use &EMR; (&EMR;) and Hive to manipulate data in &DDB;, you need the following:

listitem.para: An Amazon Web Services account. If you do not have one, you can get an account by going to http://&awsdomain;, and clicking Create an AWS Account.
A &DDB; table that contains data on the same account used with &EMR;.

A customized version of Hive that includes connectivity to &DDB;.The latest version of Hive provided by &EMR; is available by default when you launch an &EMR; &cluster; from the &console; . For more information about &EMR; AMIs and Hive versioning, go to Specifying the &EMR; AMI Version and to Configuring Hive in the &EMR; Developer Guide.
Support for &DDB; connectivity. This is included in the &EMR; AMI version 2.0.2 or later.

(Optional) An &S3; bucket. For instructions about how to create a bucket, see Get Started With Amazon Simple Storage Service. This bucket is used as a destination when exporting &DDB; data to &S3; or as a location to store a Hive script.

(Optional) A Secure Shell (SSH) client application to connect to the master node of the &EMR; &cluster; and run HiveQL queries against the &DDB; data. SSH is used to run Hive interactively. You can also save Hive commands in a text file and have &EMR; run the Hive commands from the script. In this case an SSH client is not necessary, though the ability to SSH into the master node is useful even in non-interactive &cluster;s, for debugging purposes.
An SSH client is available by default on most Linux, Unix, and Mac OS X installations. Windows users can install and use the PuTTY client, which has SSH support.

(Optional) An &EC2; key pair. This is only required for interactive &cluster;s. The key pair provides the credentials the SSH client uses to connect to the master node. If you are running the Hive commands from a script in an &S3; bucket, an EC2 key pair is optional.
